results.title: Journey to the seventh planet
results.creator_credit: Sydney Pink, Alta Vista Productions and Cinemagic Productions
results.brief_description: This passable low-budget science fiction oddity stars John Agar as the leader of a scientific mission to Uranus (not mentioned in the movie’s title in order to avoid the inevitable chuckles), where the crew fall under the control of a powerful psychic force apparently emanating from the planet itself. The entity in question is able to tap into the astronauts’ minds, giving physical form to both their greatest desires and most terrifying nightmares. As a B-movie, this film certainly rates high as a premise to “2001 a Space Odyssey” and “Solaris”.

results.title: The Brain that wouldn't die
results.creator_credit: Joseph Green, Rex Carlton, Mort Landberg and Rex Carlton Productions
results.brief_description: After a car crash, a man keeps his wife’s head alive in his laboratory. As if this weren’t enough, an evil beast pounds and screams from a locked room adjacent to the lab, for some reason the film ends with the title “The Head that Wouldn’t Die” instead of “The Brain that Wouldn’t Die.” Cast includes Jason Evers (Dr. Bill Cortner, as Herb Evers), Virginia Leith (Jan Compton), Leslie Daniels (Kurt), Adele Lamont (Doris Powell), Bonnie Sharie (Blonde Stripper), Paula Maurice (Brunette Stripper), Marilyn Hanold (Peggy Howard) and Bruce Brighton (Dr. Cortner).

results.title: Battle beyond the sun
results.creator_credit: Alexander Kozyr, Francis Ford Coppola and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: Roger Corman and future super director Francis Ford Coppola (using the pseudonym Thomas Colchart), are behind this sci-fi adventure of two warring hemispheres competing to be the first on Mars. Instead, they end up lost and landing in a small store where monsters (suspiciously shaped like male and female genitalia) constantly battle it out. The bulk of the scenes come from the Soviet sci-fi adventure Nebo Zovyot, which Corman had purchased a few years before. He dropped the cold-war aspects and assigned young Coppola to rewrite, edit and produce the film. Music by Les Baxter.

results.title: I live in fear = record of a living being = Ikimono no kiroku
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Shojiro Motoki and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Kiichi Nakajima (Mifune) decides to relocate his family to the safe haven of Brazil from what he perceives is a nuclear holocaust. His methods of getting them there, by burning down their foundry, leads to his incarceration when the family commits him for being criminally insane. From the confines of the asylum Kiichi drifts into a fantasy world where he believes that the sun is an inferno created by the Earth when it exploded in a nuclear holocaust. ‘I Live in fear’ is Kurosawa’s blatant criticism of the perils of nuclear warfare, and was produced at the height of the Cold War when the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union were all experimenting with nuclear testing. The destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki was also a recent and painful memory. This a powerful study of patriarchy in Japanese society, and what Kiichi is willing to do to convince his family to support his beliefs. Although unpopular at the box office compared to his other films, Kurosawa thought of this film as one his most proudest moments, and thus deserves due consideration. Cast includes Toshiro Mifune, Kyoko Aoyama, Minoru Chiaki and Kamatari Fujiwara.

results.title: Attack of the giant leeches
results.creator_credit: Bernard L Kowalski, Gene Corman, Roger Corman and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: After local-moonshine swilling trapper Lem Sawyer (George Cisar) sees a giant creature, people start disappearing. While searching for illegal traps Steve Benton (Ken Clark) and girl friend Nan Greyson (Jan Shepard) find Lem dying with giant sucker wounds on his body. One couple, Liz Walker (Yvette Vickers) and Cal Moulton (Michael Emmett), forced into the water by her enraged husband Dave Walker (Bruno Ve Sota), get taken by the leeches. When police refuse to believe Dave’s story, he hangs himself. Soon after this, two more trappers disappear, and local Game Warden Steve Benton gets involved. He and Nan’s father - Dr Greyson, realize that the people were taken by the leeches and the leeches live in caves under the swamp. Using dynamite, the four missing bodies are discovered, but are the leeches destroyed? Written By Leo Gordon, with music by Alexander Laszlo.

results.title: Samurai banners [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Hiroshi Inagaki, Tomoyuki Tanaka, Toshiro Mifune, Mifune Productions and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: One of the best samurai epics, “Samuarai Banners” tells the story of the 16th century warlord Takeda Shingen and his loyal general Yamamoto Kansuke (Mifune Toshiro), embedded in the story of the Takeda clan’s rise to power. Outstanding sets, costumes and Sato Masaru’s rich soundtrack make the drama highly enjoyable. The story is mainly seen from Kansuke’s point of view, and Mifune’s towering presence dominates the film. This is the final film directed by Hiroshi Inagaki, who specialised in period drama, particularly samurai films. The video cover includes information about Inakagi and Mifune as well as the context of the film. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Last time I saw Paris
results.creator_credit: Richard Brooks, Jack Cummings and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Charles Wills (Van Johnson) is a GI with literary ambitions who goes to Paris and meets and falls in love with the wealthy Helen Ellswirth (Elizabeth Taylor). Charles’ ambition to write a novel falls to pieces as failure to sell his writing causes him to turn to alcohol. During a drunken argument Johnson accidentally locks Helen out of their Parisian apartment, causing her to catch a fatal dose of pneumonia. When Helen dies, custody of their child is granted to Helen’s sister, who always disapproved of her sister’s abusive partner. Shocked into action, Charles returns home and finally finds success as a writer, and the conviction to try and regain custody of his daughter. Based on the tragic love story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cast also includes Donna Reed, Walter Pidgeon and Eva Gabor. The tape also includes interviews with Liz Taylor and Richard Burton on literary roles as well as Donna Read on location and in rehearsal.

results.title: And then there were none = Ten little indians
results.creator_credit: Rene Clair, Harry M Popkin and Popular Pictures
results.brief_description: Ten strangers, each with a criminal past, are invited to attend a party on desolate island off the English coast at the request of a mysterious host, Mr Owen. As the group settle into their sojourn, it gradually dawns on them that they have been gathered on the island to be murdered, one by one, as penance for their crimes. It seems that guests are being murdered according the nursery rhyme, “Ten little Indians”, but even knowing what murder is coming next can’t prevent it- the surviving Indians must find the mysterious Mr Owen, masquerading as one of the guests, to stop the deadly cat and mouse game. Cast includes Walter Huston, Louise Hayward, Roland Young and Judith Anderson. Based on the novel by Agatha Christie.

results.title: The Cocoanuts
results.creator_credit: Robert Florey, Joseph Santley, Walter Wanger, James R. Cowan, Monta Bell and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Another hilarious film starring Groucho, Harpo, Zeppo and Chico Marx, ‘Cocoanuts’ is one of the early talkie films and the Marx Brother’s first film. Set in Miami, Groucho Marx plays Hotel Manager, Mr Hammer, struggling to keep his establishment from going under. Hammer’s only paying guest is Mrs Potter (Margaret Dumont), whose daughter Polly (Mary Eaton) is in love with aspiring architect, Bob (Oscar Shaw). Mrs Potter would prefer that Polly marry the respectable Harvey Yates (Cyril Ring); little does she know that he is a jewel thief. Throughout this basic story the four Marx brothers create havoc in their usual slapstick manner, with hilarious results.

results.title: Stage door canteen
results.creator_credit: Frank Borzage, Sol Lesser and Sol Lesser Productions
results.brief_description: At a Stage Door Canteen in Manhattan, three enlisted men on a one-day pass to New York meet and fall in love with three hostesses working there (Cheryl Walker, Marjorie Riordan, Dorothea Kent). This film is noted for its 60 plus celebrities who star as themselves, rather than the love story that provides the backdrop for their appearance. The setting allows for a cavalcade of musical and comedy numbers as well as cameo appearances. Cast also includes William Terry, Lon McCallister and Michael Harrison.
